meanings.definition: prison:
examples: I always knew he'd end up in (the) jug.

meanings.definition: a large container for liquids that usually has a handle and a narrow opening at the top
a small group of performers who play jazz, blues, or folk music on very simple musical instruments, especially using objects such as empty jugs as instruments:
examples: Their music uses of a host of jug band instruments, including wash tub bass, spoons, and, of course, a jug.
His recordings featured electrified ensembles, jug bands and jazz groups.

meanings.definition: the amount held by a jug:
examples: There was a jugful of water on each table.
I poured a whole jugful of milk into the pan.

meanings.definition: a very large, heavy truck:
examples: The peace of the village has been shattered by juggernauts thundering through it.

meanings.definition: a large powerful force or organization that cannot be stopped
a very large and powerful company, organization, or industry:
examples: Health care has turned into something of a juggernaut in the economy recently.
Concerns have been expressed that the FTSE 100 juggernaut could be slowed by the impact of a rising dollar.
commercial/economic/financial juggernaut

meanings.definition: a very large truck used for transporting large quantities of goods
to throw several objects up into the air, and then catch and throw them up repeatedly so that one or more stays in the air, usually in order to entertain people:
examples: We all watched in amazement as he juggled with three flaming torches.

meanings.definition: to succeed in arranging your life so that you have time to involve yourself in two or more different activities or groups of people:
examples: Many parents find it hard to juggle children and a career.

meanings.definition: to change results or information recorded as numbers so that a situation seems to be better than it really is:
examples: It won't matter if we juggle the figures - no one will know.

meanings.definition: to throw several objects into the air, catch them, and keep them moving so that at least one is always in the air:
examples: fig. Many women find it hard to juggle a family and a career (= to arrange their lives so that they have time for both).

meanings.definition: to try to do two or more jobs or activities at the same time, because you do not have a lot of time:
examples: Senior executives are under pressure to juggle the increasing demands of their workload.
Flexible working hours help staff juggle work and family life.

meanings.definition: if you juggle data or resources, you use them in a way that will bring you an advantage or that may be dishonest:
examples: Analysts think the Treasury may be able to juggle its accounts for the next few months.

meanings.definition: to buy and sell shares, bonds, etc. on a regular basis in order to make a lot of money:
examples: While individual investors may be able to juggle asset allocation themselves, diversifying into 100 or more different assets usually requires a professional fund manager.

meanings.definition: a liquid used in devices used for vaping (= breathing in nicotine as vapour using devices such as e-cigarettes):

meanings.definition: in a way that produces a lot of juice, or tastes or smells of juice:

meanings.definition: in a way that is especially interesting because of being shocking or personal:

meanings.definition: the quality of containing a lot of juice and being enjoyable to eat:

meanings.definition: the process of getting the juice out of fruit and vegetables:

meanings.definition: big, important, or of a high quality:
examples: If sales continue like this, we should be showing a nice juicy profit at the end of the year.

meanings.definition: full of juice or juices and therefore enjoyable to eat:

examples: They have tried to eliminate juju, or witchcraft, but it still has many believers.

meanings.definition: an object that has been given magical power, especially in the traditional belief systems of some West African countries:
examples: The witch doctor assured the villagers that his jujus would protect them.
He said the bag of herbs, coffee beans wrapped in dry banana leaves, dead fireflies and bats was a juju, but he was not worried by it as he did not believe in witchcraft.

meanings.definition: magic or a mysterious quality that gives something power, brings good luck, or makes something succeed:
examples: Words, like objects, can lose their juju over time.

meanings.definition: a small round fruit that grows on a tree, also called a jujube
a small fruit-flavoured sweet

examples: The wide receiver juked the defender at the line of scrimmage and was able to get open in the end zone to catch the touchdown pass.
The running back juked around the cornerback and was able to pick up another ten yards and a first down.

meanings.definition: to cut food, especially vegetables, into long thin pieces:

meanings.definition: a very large video screen like those used in sports stadiums (= large areas of land with rows of seats and often no roof where people watch sports):

meanings.definition: to push yourself suddenly off the ground and into the air using your legs:
examples: The children were jumping up and down with excitement.
She ran across the grass and jumped into the water.
He had to jump out of an upstairs window to escape.
Our cat is always jumping up on/onto the furniture.

meanings.definition: to push yourself suddenly off the ground in order to go over something:
examples: Can you jump over/across this stream?
All the horses are finding it difficult to jump the last fence.

meanings.definition: to move or act suddenly or quickly:
examples: He suddenly jumped to his feet/jumped up and left.
She jumped in/into a taxi and rushed to the station.

meanings.definition: If a noise or action causes you to jump, your body makes a sudden sharp movement because of surprise or fear:
examples: The loud explosion made everyone jump.
I almost jumped out of my skin when I heard a loud crash downstairs.

meanings.definition: to increase suddenly by a large amount:
examples: House prices have jumped dramatically.
The cost of building the road has jumped by 70 percent.

meanings.definition: If a story, film, play, etc. jumps, it moves suddenly between different parts of it:
examples: The movie is about his adult life, but it keeps jumping (back) to when he was a child.
His talk was hard to follow because he kept jumping from one subject to another.

meanings.definition: to avoid or leave out a point or stage from the correct order in a series:
examples: You have to follow the instructions exactly, you can't just jump a few steps ahead.

meanings.definition: to attack someone suddenly:
examples: They were just walking home when a bunch of guys jumped (on) them.

meanings.definition: to go past or away from something illegally or wrongly:
examples: The police video showed that she had jumped the (traffic) lights.
Several sailors jumped ship (= left their ship without permission) in New York.

meanings.definition: a sudden movement off the ground and into the air:
examples: He won with a jump of 8.5 metres.
a parachute jump
Several horses fell at the last jump (= fence or other thing to be jumped over).

meanings.definition: a sudden sharp movement because of surprise or fear:
examples: The door slammed and Rita woke up with a jump.

meanings.definition: a sudden increase:
examples: Interest rates are now at 6.75 - that's a jump of almost 2 percent.

meanings.definition: to push yourself off the ground and into the air using your legs and feet:
examples: The kids were jumping up and down with excitement.
The cats jumped up onto the table.

meanings.definition: To jump sometimes means to lift yourself off the ground in order to go over something:
examples: Can you jump this fence?

meanings.definition: to move suddenly or quickly:
examples: A man jumped out of the bushes.
He jumped to his feet and ran out the door.

meanings.definition: If a noise or action causes you to jump, your body makes a sudden movement because of surprise or fear:
examples: The thunder made us all jump.

meanings.definition: to move up or go across suddenly from one point or stage to another without stopping at the stages in between:
examples: Her book jumped from fifth place to first place on the best-seller list.
The forest fire jumped the road and spread to the other side.

meanings.definition: to increase suddenly by a large amount:
examples: Home prices in the area have jumped to an all-time high.

meanings.definition: to attack suddenly:
examples: He was jumped and robbed by two guys on his way home from work.

meanings.definition: a push into the air from a surface, like the ground or ice, using your legs and feet:
examples: The skater’s jump was high but not graceful.

meanings.definition: a move from one point or stage to another without stopping at the stages in between:
examples: He made a big jump from general manager to president of the company.

meanings.definition: if prices, profits, shares, etc. jump, they increase by a large amount in a short period of time:
examples: Interest rates look set to jump over the coming months.
The PMI index jumped from 54.5 to 56.1 in March, its highest level for six years.
The airline's full-year pre-tax profits jumped 56% despite the impact of higher oil prices.
Overall music sales have jumped more than 19 percent in the last twelve months.

meanings.definition: a sudden large increase in the price, value, or amount of something:
examples: The tech stocks in the index posted the biggest jumps.
Universities and colleges have reported a dramatic jump in the number of applications.
Net casino revenues increased by 19% to $41 million, a jump of 138% over the fourth quarter of 2008.
Heavyweight stock helped to drag the FTSE 100 higher with a 27.5p jump to 742p.
The increase in home repossessions, showing a 31% jump from last year's figures, is depressing property values.
a jump in profits/sales/inflation
a big/sharp/significant jump

meanings.definition: to criticize someone suddenly and severely:
examples: When I showed him my report card, Dad jumped all over me.

meanings.definition: infml to criticize someone suddenly and severely:
examples: When I showed him my report card, Dad jumped all over me and said I wasn’t working hard enough.

meanings.definition: to accept something eagerly:
examples: She jumped at the chance of a trip to Paris.

meanings.definition: to accept an opportunity eagerly:
examples: She jumped at the chance to go to Paris.

meanings.definition: to quickly take advantage of a new opportunity:
examples: Many people jump at the chance to work overseas, seeing it as a way of earning far more than they could in their own country.

meanings.definition: to fail to appear for a court trial after being released until the trial in exchange for payment:
examples: I'd never have thought Hugh would jump bail.
My role is to track down defendants who jump bail.
He was indicted for jumping bail.
Robinson jumped bail while awaiting trial on fraud charges.
Four of the defendants jumped bail and fled the country.

meanings.definition: in basketball, an action in which the referee throws the ball in the air between two players from opposing teams to start the game again after it has stopped:
examples: Each half will start with a jump ball.
He hit the shot after Martin won a jump ball and tapped the ball to him.

meanings.definition: a situation in which a decision or advantage could go in one of two ways, especially where it is difficult to guess the result:
examples: In the big picture of this campaign, this issue is a jump ball.
It's pretty much a jump ball.

meanings.definition: to react angrily to something that someone says or does:
examples: I made the mildest of criticisms and he jumped down my throat.

meanings.definition: to be extremely happy:
examples: "So how did Robert take the news?" "He didn't exactly jump for joy."

meanings.definition: in basketball, a movement in which a player jumps in the air and uses their arm stretched out to the side to throw the ball sideways over their head to try to get it into the basket:
examples: He made a huge jump hook in the lane late in the game.

meanings.definition: to interrupt when someone else is speaking:
examples: I wish you'd stop jumping in and finishing my sentences for me all the time.

meanings.definition: to suddenly become involved in a situation or discussion:
examples: Investors said they wouldn't be surprised if some companies jumped in to borrow in case rates rise further.

jump-in-at-the-deep-end.name: jump in at the deep end

meanings.definition: If you jump or are thrown in at the deep end, you start doing something new and difficult without help or preparation.
to become involved in a situation too quickly without thinking about it first:
examples: That's just like Julie - always jumping in with both feet before she knows the facts.

meanings.definition: to suddenly decide to do something, especially without thinking about it carefully:
examples: Investors shouldn't jump into moving their funds without carefully reviewing their financial situation.

meanings.definition: a pair of thick wires for starting the engine of one vehicle with electricity from the battery of another vehicle
to criticize someone as soon as they have done something wrong or said something that you disagree with:
examples: She jumps on her children instantly if they're disobedient.

meanings.definition: to get on a plane, train, etc. to go somewhere quickly:
examples: He jumped on a plane and flew out to Chicago for the convention.

meanings.definition: to join an activity that has become very popular or to change your opinion to one that has become very popular so that you can share in its success:
examples: After a couple of politicians won elections by promising to cut taxes, most of the others jumped on the bandwagon.

meanings.definition: If something jumps out at you, you notice it immediately:
examples: That's a very effective advertisement - it really jumps out at you.

meanings.definition: a rope that is used for jumping over as an exercise or game:
examples: Set up a mini gym at home with a yoga mat, hand weights and a jump rope.
The kids were busy playing with jump ropes and skateboards.

meanings.definition: to jump lightly over a rope that is held in both your hands, or by two other people, and turned repeatedly under your legs and over your head as exercise or a game:
examples: Why not jump rope, play hopscotch, walk, jog or take a dance class?

meanings.definition: a rope that you pass over your head and under your feet while jumping, for exercise or amusement:
examples: We grabbed our jump rope and headed for the playground.

meanings.definition: something, such as a scene in a film, that shocks and frightens you so that you suddenly move or jump:
examples: This film has so many jump scares, the audience are jumping out of their seats every fifteen seconds.
He loves watching jumpscare videos on the internet.

meanings.definition: in basketball, an attempt to score in which the player throws the ball towards the basket while jumping in the air:
examples: We were practising jump shots in the gym.
He turned to watch the jumpshot drop through the rim like a door slamming shut.

meanings.definition: an exercise in which you squat (= position yourself close to the ground balancing on the front part of your feet with your legs bent under your body) before jumping up to land with your knees and hips bent:
examples: Jump squats work the entire lower body.
He does 20 squat jumps before he takes a shower.

meanings.definition: in basketball, an act of running and coming to a stop by jumping and landing on both feet at the same time, often before making a pass (= throw to another player) or taking a shot (= attempt to score a goal):
examples: Players are trained to come to a jump stop when they stop dribbling so they aren’t given a foul for travelling.
The coach makes the players do a drill where they do a jump stop, shoot the ball, and then grab the rebound.

meanings.definition: to do something too soon, especially without thinking carefully about it:
examples: They've only just met - isn't it jumping the gun to be talking about marriage already?

meanings.definition: to act too soon or before the right time:
examples: They only met three weeks ago – isn’t it jumping the gun to start talking about marriage?

meanings.definition: to move to the front of a line of people who are waiting for something, so that you are served or dealt with before them: to be dealt with earlier than other people who are also waiting for something and who may have been waiting longer than you:
examples: This pre-paid smart card allows you to jump the queue to 60 of the capital's favourite attractions.
When the All Clear sounded we queued up again. No one jumped the queue.
Under this plan the better-off will be able to jump the queue by paying for private health care.
Claims that immigrants jump the queue for council houses are incorrect, the Institute for Public Policy Research says.

meanings.definition: (usually of television shows) to reach a point where something stops becoming more popular or starts to decrease in quality:
examples: The show jumped the shark a few years ago.
Will Twitter soon jump the shark?

meanings.definition: to have to do a lot of things that seem difficult or unnecessary in order to achieve something:
examples: We had to jump through hoops to get my Dad admitted to hospital.

meanings.definition: to do a lot of extra things, esp. silly or difficult things, to achieve something:
examples: We had to jump through hoops to get my Dad admitted to the hospital.

meanings.definition: to guess the facts about a situation without having enough information:
examples: Don't jump to conclusions! Perhaps it was his daughter he was dancing with.

meanings.definition: used to tell someone to do something quickly:
examples: I told you to tidy this room - now jump to it!

meanings.definition: to start a car engine by pushing the car or by using jump leads
to improve a situation by taking a particular action:
examples: Companies want lower interest rates to jump-start the nation's weak economy.

meanings.definition: to start or improve something more quickly by giving it extra help:
examples: These recordings jump-started her career.

meanings.definition: If you jump-start a car, you start its engine by using wires to carry electric power from another car’s engine.

just-to-be-on-the-safe-side.name: (just) to be on the safe side

meanings.definition: being especially careful in order to avoid something unpleasant:
examples: I'm sure it won't rain, but I'll take an umbrella (just) to be on the safe side (= to be ready if it does rain).

meanings.definition: used as a way of threatening someone:
examples: Just you wait, Maria, till I get my hands on you!

meanings.definition: A just-in-time system of manufacturing (= producing goods) is based on preventing waste by producing only the amount of goods needed at a particular time, and not paying to produce and store more goods than are needed.

relating to a manufacturing system in which parts and materials are delivered when they are needed, rather than before. Just-in-time systems reduce the cost of storing parts and materials and reduce waste:
examples: Selling direct to customers means the company can buy components on a just-in-time basis.
a just-in-time delivery/inventory system
just-in-time manufacturing/production

meanings.definition: perfectly tidy and well arranged:
examples: He's a perfectionist - everything has to be just so.
I've never known anyone so neat. Everything in her closet is exactly so.
He likes things just so and can tell when someone else has been working at his desk.
I need to make sure everything is just so for Polly.
He insists on having everything exactly so and it drives her mad.

meanings.definition: fairness in the way people are dealt with:
examples: There's no justice in the world when people can be made to suffer like that.
The winner has been disqualified for cheating, so justice has been done (= a fair situation has been achieved).

meanings.definition: the system of laws in a country that judges and punishes people:
examples: the justice system in this country consists of a series of law courts at different levels.
The police are doing all they can to bring those responsible for the bombing to justice.
They are victims of a miscarriage of justice (= when the law has been carried out wrongly).
He has been accused of obstructing the course of justice (= preventing the law being put into action).

meanings.definition: a judge in a law court:
examples: The president is expected to name a new Supreme Court justice within the next few days.
Justice Ben Overton

meanings.definition: used before the name of a judge in the High Court:
examples: Mr Justice Ellis

meanings.definition: the condition of being morally correct or fair:
examples: He accused the police of false arrest and demanded justice.

meanings.definition: the system of laws by which people are judged and punished:
examples: the criminal justice system

meanings.definition: a judge, esp. of one of the higher courts of law:
examples: a justice of the US Supreme Court

meanings.definition: the system of laws within a country or state by which people are judged and punished:
examples: The decision was welcomed as a great day for the British justice system.
Prosecutors alleged that she had obstructed justice by lying to investigators.
local/international justice
Under the new scheme, victims of miscarriages of justice would be entitled to compensation.

meanings.definition: the quality of being fair and right:
examples: We want justice for those who have suffered because of the company's actions.
social/racial justice

meanings.definition: in the US, a judge in a court of law, especially a higher court:
examples: a Supreme Court/Chief Justice

meanings.definition: in the UK, a title used before the name of a judge in the High Court:
examples: Mr Justice Cooke

meanings.definition: a person who is not a lawyer but who acts as a judge in local law courts and, in the US, can marry people
a public officer who judges local and less important legal cases, and performs marriage ceremonies
a magistrate who deals with less serious crimes and who, in the US, has the legal right to marry people:
examples: In most cases involving a small amount of money, people appear before a justice of the peace and pay a fine.

meanings.definition: able to be decided in a court of law:
examples: There are real questions as to whether matters of this kind are properly justiciable.
There were no further justiciable issues for the court to adjudicate upon.

meanings.definition: If something is justifiable, there is a good reason for it:
examples: Her actions were quite justifiable in the circumstances.

meanings.definition: able to be explained or shown to be reasonable; understandable:
examples: The jury decided that the shooting was justifiable because Rogers thought his own life was in danger.

meanings.definition: an act of killing someone that the law allows because it considers that there is a good reason for it, for example if you are defending yourself
in a way for which there is a good reason:
examples: He was justifiably proud of his achievements.
People are justifiably angry.

meanings.definition: a good reason or explanation for something:
examples: There is no justification for treating people so badly.
It can be said, with some justification, that she is one of the greatest actresses on the English stage today.

meanings.definition: given as, containing, or relating to a justification (= reason or explanation) for something you have done, especially something bad:
examples: Many of the justificatory pretexts and rationalizations expressed today are similar to those advanced in the Third Reich.
He acknowledged his lies and other wrongdoings in a justificatory counter-narrative.

meanings.definition: having a good reason for something:
examples: I accept that the criticism is completely justified.
I think you were quite justified in complaining.

meanings.definition: to give or to be a good reason for:
examples: I can't really justify taking another day off work.
Are you sure that these measures are justified?

meanings.definition: to show that something is reasonable, right, or true:
examples: Her fears of a low voter turnout were justified when fewer than half of the people voted.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         justify
to give or to be a good reason for:
examples: I can't really justify taking another day off work.
Are you sure that these measures are justified?

meanings.definition: in a fair or morally correct way:
examples: He was justly condemned to a long prison sentence.
Kenji Mizoguchi is justly recognized as one of Japanese cinema’s greatest figures.

meanings.definition: in a morally correct way; fairly:
examples: We agreed that he was justly condemned to a long prison sentence.

meanings.definition: Justly also means with good reason or rightly:
examples: Kenji Mizoguchi is justly recognized as one of Japanese cinema’s greatest figures.

meanings.definition: the quality of being fair or morally correct:
examples: They believe in the moral justness of their mission.
We are confident in the justness of our cause.

meanings.word_type: verb[ I or T,  usually + adv/prep ]
meanings.definition: to (cause to) stick out, especially above or past the edge or surface of something:
examples: The pier juts (out) into the lake.
He jutted his chin/jaw (out) defiantly.

meanings.definition: to stick out, esp. above or beyond the edge or surface of something:
examples: A large ship was docked at the pier that jutted out into the harbor.

meanings.definition: a substance that comes from a Southeast Asian plant, used for making rope and cloth
sticking out, especially above or past the edge or surface of something:
examples: jutting rocks
He had a large head and jutting jaw.

meanings.definition: relating to a young person who is not yet old enough to be considered an adult:
examples: juvenile crime/offenders
He was later taken to juvenile detention for violating the terms of his parole.

meanings.definition: affecting children rather than adults:
examples: The following year, he was diagnosed with juvenile diabetes.
juvenile arthritis

meanings.definition: A juvenile animal is young and not fully grown:
examples: juvenile salmon
juvenile crabs

meanings.definition: silly and typical of a child:
examples: juvenile behaviour
a juvenile sense of humour
He was ridiculed in a rather juvenile and at times spiteful way.

meanings.definition: a person who is not old enough to be considered an adult:
examples: He was still a juvenile when the crime was committed.
Some of those programs fail in that they transfer juveniles to adult correctional systems

meanings.definition: a young animal that is not yet fully grown:
examples: The marsh protects fish eggs and juveniles that need to evade predators until they can mature and move into open water.

meanings.definition: of, by, or for a young person who is not yet an adult:
examples: He studied both adult and juvenile crime.

meanings.definition: crime that is committed by young people:
examples: Lack of parental control is seen to lie behind drug abuse and juvenile delinquency.
The court averages more than 3,000 cases of juvenile delinquency each year.

meanings.definition: criminal activity by people under 18 years old
a young person who commits crimes
a young person, usually under 18, who commits a crime
a form of prison for young people below a certain age who have committed a crime:
examples: The number of youths taken to juvenile detention has fallen.
The state's juvenile incarceration rate is a third of the national rate.

meanings.definition: a type of prison where young people can be kept:
examples: The judge sentenced her to three months at a juvenile detention center.

meanings.definition: a type of prison for people who are not old enough to be considered as adults:
examples: He served a short stint in juvenile hall in connection with a robbery.
The agreement requires that juvenile halls be adequately staffed with mental health specialists.

meanings.definition: the most important part that is performed by a young actor in a play or film:
examples: Rachael is playing the juvenile lead in the Christmas show.

meanings.definition: work produced by an artist when he or she was young, especially when it is published or known only after the artist has become famous later:
examples: The archive covers the author's entire literary and professional life, from her earliest juvenilia to her final lectures and articles.

meanings.definition: the quality of being juvenile (= behaving in a way that is silly and typical of a child):
examples: My occasional lapses into juvenility seemed to pain him.
Juvenility is rampant in contemporary culture.

meanings.definition: short for juvenile detention centre: a type of prison for people who are not old enough to be considered as adults:
examples: He spent the bulk of his adolescence in and out of juvie.
If I was caught, I'd be in juvie hall for a pretty long time.

meanings.definition: to put things that are not similar next to each other:
examples: The exhibition juxtaposes Picasso's early drawings with some of his later works.

meanings.definition: to put things or people next to each other, esp. in order to compare them:
examples: The exhibition juxtaposes architectural drawings with photographs of the buildings as constructed.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         juxtapose
to put things that are not similar next to each other:
examples: The exhibition juxtaposes Picasso's early drawings with some of his later works.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         juxtapose
to put things that are not similar next to each other:
examples: The exhibition juxtaposes Picasso's early drawings with some of his later works.

meanings.definition: the fact of putting things that are not similar next to each other:
examples: the juxtaposition of two very different cultures
An odd juxtaposition of talents worked exceedingly well on the project.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for 
        
         joint venture
